revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} Since first coming to wide notice in the late 1990s, the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' book series by [[J. K. Rowling]] has engendered a number of legal disputes. Rowling, her various publishers and [[Time Warner]], the owner of the rights to the [[Harry Potter (film series)|''Harry Potter'' films]], have taken numerous legal actions to protect their copyrights, and also have fielded accusations of copyright theft themselves.<ref name="Potter author zaps court rival">{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/WORLD/europe/UK/09/19/rowling.court/index.html|publisher=CNN|title=Potter author zaps court rival|date=19 July 2002|accessdate=11 March 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629165519/http://archives.cnn.com/2002/WORLD/europe/UK/09/19/rowling.court/index.html|archivedate=29 June 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The worldwide popularity of the ''Harry Potter'' series has led to the appearance of a number of locally produced, unauthorised sequels and other derivative works, sparking efforts to ban or contain them.<ref name=yemets>{{cite web|url=http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/mpapps/pagetools/print/news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/2846105.stm|title=Rowling seeks 'Grotter' ban|publisher=BBC News|date=13 March 2003|accessdate=31 March 2006}}</ref> While these legal proceedings have countered a number of cases of outright piracy,<ref name=walkup>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/2092661.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Fake Harry Potter novel hits China|date=4 July 2002|accessdate=11 March 2007}}</ref> other attempts have targeted not-for-profit endeavours and have been criticised.<ref name=Claire>{{cite web|title=Warner Brothers bullying ruins Field family Xmas|author=Kieren McCarthy|publisher=The Register|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2000/12/21/warner_brothers_bullying_ruins_field/ |date=21 December 2000|accessdate=3 May 2007}}</ref>
Another area of legal dispute involves a series of injunctions obtained by Rowling and her publishers to prohibit anyone from distributing or reading her books before their official release dates. The sweeping powers of these injunctions have occasionally drawn fire from civil liberties and free speech campaigners and sparked debates over the "right to read".<ref name="Don't Buy Harry Potter Books">{{cite web|url=http://stallman.org/harry-potter.html|title=Don't Buy Harry Potter Books|year=2005|author=Richard Stallman|publisher=stallman.org|accessdate=13 March 2007}}</ref><ref name=geist>{{cite web|title=Harry Potter and the Right to Read|author=Michael Geist|publisher=michaelgeist.ca|url=http://www.michaelgeist.ca/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=896|date=17 July 2005|accessdate=12 October 2007}}{{cite news|work=The [[Toronto Star]]|date=18 July 2005|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/868524161.html?dids=868524161:868524161&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+18%2C+2005&author=Michael+Geist&pub=Toronto+Star&edition=&startpage=C.03&desc=Harry+Potter+and+the+amazing+injunction|title=Appeared in|accessdate=26 September 2008 | first=Michael | last=Geist}}</ref> One of these injunctions was used in an unrelated trespassing case as precedent supporting the issuance of an injunction against a [[John Doe]].<ref name=injunction>{{cite web|title=Hampshire Waste Services Ltd v. Intending Trespassers upon Chineham Incinerator Site|author=Sir Andrew Morritt V.C |publisher=High Court of Justice (Chancery Division) Ch D|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:hzDg_VqvnI0J:oxcheps.new.ox.ac.uk/new/casebook/cases/Cases%2520Chapter%252023/Hampshire%2520Waste%2520Services%2520Ltd%2520v%2520Intending%2520Trespassers%2520Upon%2520Chineham%2520Incinerator%2520Site.doc+%22the+person+or+persons+who+has+or+have+physical+possession+of+a+copy+of+the+said+book+or+any+part+thereof+without+the+consent+of+the+Claimants%22&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=1&gl=uk|year=2004|accessdate=23 August 2008}} (kept at: [http://oxcheps.new.ox.ac.uk/ Oxford Center for Higher Education Policy Studies])</ref>
Outside these controversies, a number of particular incidents related to ''Harry Potter'' have also led, or almost led, to legal action. In 2005, a man was sentenced to four years in prison after firing a replica gun at a journalist during a staged deal for stolen copies of an unreleased ''Harry Potter'' novel, and attempting to blackmail the publisher with threats of releasing secrets from the book.<ref name=corby>{{cite news|title=Man jailed for Potter theft|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/jan/19/pressandpublishing.ukcrime|date=19 January 2006|work=The Guardian |location=London|accessdate=23 May 2007 | first=Mark | last=Oliver}}</ref> Then in 2007 [[Bloomsbury Publishing]] contemplated legal action against the supermarket chain [[Asda]] for libel after the company accused them of overpricing the final ''Harry Potter'' novel, ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]''.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|title=Asda barred from selling seventh Harry Potter|author=Nigel Reynolds|work=The Telegraph|date=17 July 2007|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1557690/Asda-barred-from-selling-seventh-Harry-Potter.html|accessdate=1 August 2007 | location=London}}</ref> A comprehensive list of intellectual property and speech lawsuits involving ''Harry Potter'', [http://www.trademarkandcopyrightlawblog.com/2015/07/harry-potter-lawsuits-and-where-to-find-them/ Harry Potter Lawsuits and Where to Find Them], was compiled by attorney [http://www.foleyhoag.com/people/kluft-david David Kluft] in 2015 for the [http://www.trademarkandcopyrightlawblog.com/ Trademark and Copyright Law Blog].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.trademarkandcopyrightlawblog.com/2015/07/harry-potter-lawsuits-and-where-to-find-them/|title=Harry Potter Lawsuits and Where to Find Them {{!}} Trademark and Copyright Law|website=www.trademarkandcopyrightlawblog.com|access-date=2016-06-10}}</ref>
== Allegations of copyright and trademark infringement against Rowling == {{See also|Harry Potter influences and analogues}}
=== Nancy Stouffer === In 1999, American author Nancy Kathleen Stouffer alleged [[copyright infringement|copyright]] and [[trademark infringement]] by Rowling of her 1984 works ''The Legend of Rah and the Muggles'' ({{ISBN|1-58989-400-6}}) and ''Larry Potter and His Best Friend Lilly''.<ref name="Potter author zaps court rival" /> The primary basis for Stouffer's case rested in her own purported invention of the word "[[Muggle]]s", the name of a race of [[mutant]] [[humanoids]] in ''The Legend of Rah and the Muggles'', and Larry Potter, the title character of a series of activity booklets for children. Larry Potter, like Harry Potter, is a bespectacled boy with dark hair,<ref name="Muggle Versus Wizard" /> though he is not a character in ''The Legend of Rah and the Muggles''.<ref>{{cite news|title='Harry Potter' Prevails In Court|author=Hillel Italie|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/09/19/print/main522563.shtml|publisher=CBS News|date=19 September 2002|accessdate=8 May 2008}}</ref> Stouffer also drew a number of other comparisons, such as a castle on a lake, a receiving room and wooden doors.<ref name="Muggle Versus Wizard">{{cite news|url=http://discuss.washingtonpost.com/zforum/01/author_stouffer032801.htm|work=The Washington Post|title=Muggle Versus Wizard|date=28 March 2001|accessdate=11 March 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070518113345/http://discuss.washingtonpost.com/zforum/01/author_stouffer032801.htm|archivedate=18 May 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Portions of ''Rah'' were originally published in booklet form in 1986 by Ande Publishing Company, a company founded by Stouffer together with a group of friends and family.<ref name="opinion">Scholastic, Inc. v. Stouffer 221 F. Supp. 2d 425 ([[Southern District of New York|S.D.N.Y.]] 2002)</ref> Ande Publishing filed for bankruptcy in September 1987 without selling any of its booklets in the United States or elsewhere.<ref name="opinion" /> Rowling has stated that she first visited the United States in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=All Things Considered: Harry Potter|date=3 December 1998|publisher=NPR Radio |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1032154|accessdate=3 September 2008}} (Rowling interview)</ref>
Rowling, along with [[Scholastic Press]] (her American publisher) and [[Warner Bros.]] (holders of the series' film rights), pre-empted Stouffer in 2002 with a suit of their own seeking a [[declaratory judgment]] that they had not infringed on any of Stouffer's works. The court found in Rowling's favour, granting summary judgment and holding that "no reasonable juror could find a likelihood of confusion as to the source of the two parties' works".<ref name=opinion /> During the course of the trial, it was held that Rowling proved "by clear and convincing evidence, that Stouffer has perpetrated a fraud on the Court through her submission of fraudulent documents as well as through her untruthful testimony",<ref name="opinion" /> including changing pages years after the fact to retroactively insert the word "muggle".<ref name="opinion" /> Her case was dismissed with prejudice and she was fined $50,000 for her "pattern of intentional bad faith conduct" in relation to her employment of fraudulent submissions, along with being ordered to pay a portion of the plaintiffs' legal fees.<ref name="opinion" /> Stouffer appealed the decision in 2004, but in 2005 the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|Second Circuit Court of Appeals]] affirmed the ruling.<ref>''Scholastic Inc. v. Stouffer'', 81 F. App'x 396 (2d Cir. 2003)</ref> In 2006 she stated on her website that she was planning to republish her books and was entertaining the possibility of another lawsuit against Warner Bros., J. K. Rowling and Scholastic Press.<ref name="unauth" />
''The Legend of Rah and the Muggles'' is currently out of print. In early 2001, it was published by Thurman House, LLC, a Maryland publishing company.<ref name="opinion" /> Thurman House, formed by [[Ottenheimer Publishers]] to republish the works of Nancy Stouffer, was closed when Ottenheimer ceased operations in 2002 after filing for bankruptcy.<ref name="pw">{{cite web|url=http://new.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20020617/22500-ottenheimer-closing-down-.html|title=Ottenheimer Closing Down|work=Publishers Weekly|date=17 June 2002|accessdate=19 September 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715131909/http://new.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20020617/22500-ottenheimer-closing-down-.html#|archive-date=15 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Stouffer later asserted that any copies of the book published by Thurman House are unauthorized because the publisher failed to honour its contractual obligations to her.<ref name="unauth">{{cite web|title=realmuggles.com|author=Nancy Stouffer|url=http://www.realmuggles.com/action.html#notice1|accessdate=18 October 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071028093257/http://www.realmuggles.com/action.html#notice1#notice1|archive-date=28 October 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== The Wyrd Sisters === In 2005, Warner Bros. offered CAD$5,000 (later CAD$50,000) to the Canadian folk band the [[Wyrd Sisters (band)|Wyrd Sisters]] for the rights to use their name in the film version of ''[[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire]]''.<ref name=chart>{{cite web|title=Winnipeg's Wyrd Sisters Still Fighting Harry Potter |url=http://www.chartattack.com/news/41504/winnipegs-wyrd-sisters-still-fighting-harry-potter |date=7 April 2006 |publisher=[[Chart (magazine)|''Chart'' magazine]] |accessdate=23 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090405020832/http://www.chartattack.com/news/41504/winnipegs-wyrd-sisters-still-fighting-harry-potter |archivedate=5 April 2009 }}</ref> Rowling had written a scene in the novel in which a band called the [[The Weird Sisters (Harry Potter)|Weird Sisters]] appeared at a school dance, and the group owned the rights to the name in Canada. However, the offer was declined, and instead the band undertook a legal action against Warner Bros., as well as [[Jarvis Cocker]] of [[Pulp (band)|Pulp]] and [[Jonny Greenwood]] and [[Phil Selway]] of [[Radiohead]], who were to play the band in the film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2005/11/04/wyrdlawsuit_051104.html |title='Wyrd Sisters' cannot stop Harry Potter |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |date=4 September 2005 |accessdate=3 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070527023912/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2005/11/04/wyrdlawsuit_051104.html |archivedate=27 May 2007 }}</ref> All plans to use the name in the movie were later abandoned. Despite that decision, the Canadian band filed a CAD$40-million ($39 million) lawsuit against Warner in Ontario court. In connection with the lawsuit, the band brought an [[interlocutory]] [[injunction]] hoping to prevent the release of the film. The injunction application was dismissed.<ref name=wyrd /> The entire suit was dismissed in November 2005. In June 2006, an Ontario judge decreed that the band pay Warner Bros. CAD$140,000 in legal costs, describing their lawsuit as "highly intrusive".<ref name=wyrd /><ref name=sisters /> The group claimed they planned to appeal the decision.<ref name=wyrd>{{cite news|title=Wyrd Sisters continue Harry Potter battle with studio |url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2006/07/03/wyrd-potter-court.html |publisher=The [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=3 July 2006 |accessdate=23 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070507075524/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2006/07/03/wyrd-potter-court.html |archivedate=7 May 2007 }}</ref> Jarvis Cocker initially wished to release an album of "Weird Sisters"-themed music with collaborators including [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], [[Jack White (musician)|Jack White]] and [[Iggy Pop]], but the project was dropped as a result of the lawsuit.<ref name=sisters>{{cite web|title=Winnipeg folk band that took on Harry Potter ordered to pay $140,000 court costs |date=1 July 2006 |author=Adrian Humphreys |work=The [[National Post]] |url=http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=bc5b3049-56dc-493b-9ccc-5d4bd0389392 |accessdate=3 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016153617/http://canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=bc5b3049-56dc-493b-9ccc-5d4bd0389392 |archivedate=16 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> The Wyrd Sisters reported [[death threats]] from irate ''Harry Potter'' fans.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wyrd Sisters keep fighting the good fight, fan mail or not|author=Leah Collins|work=The [[Vancouver Sun]]|date=4 August 2007|url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/arts/story.html?id=ece18f65-1eb9-4829-9e2b-1d50a0dca298|accessdate=26 September 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929144426/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/arts/story.html?id=ece18f65-1eb9-4829-9e2b-1d50a0dca298|archivedate=29 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As of March 2010, the lawsuit has been settled out of court, the details sealed.<ref>{{cite web |first=Steve |last=Lambert |title=Wyrd five-year court battle over Harry Potter movie ends with secret settlement |url=http://www.news919.com/news/national/article/39866--wyrd-five-year-court-battle-over-harry-potter-movie-ends-with-secret-settlement |publisher=Canadian Press |location=Winnipeg |year=2010 |accessdate=28 March 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714174133/http://www.news919.com/news/national/article/39866--wyrd-five-year-court-battle-over-harry-potter-movie-ends-with-secret-settlement# |archive-date=14 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Adrian Jacobs === In June 2009, the estate of Adrian Jacobs, a children's author who died in 1997, sued Rowling's publishers, Bloomsbury, for £500 million, accusing her of having plagiarised "substantial parts" of his work in writing the novel ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire''.<ref>{{cite news|title=JK Rowling sued for £500m in plagiarism lawsuit by family of late ''Willy The Wizard'' author|work=Daily Mail |location=UK |author=Ryan Kisiel|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1193283/JK-Rowling-sued-500m-plagiarism-lawsuit-family-late-Willy-The-Wizard-author.html|accessdate=16 June 2009 | date=16 June 2009}}</ref><ref name=straits>{{cite web|title=Rowling didn't plagiarise |publisher=Reuters |year=2009 |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Lifestyle/Story/STIStory_390898.html |accessdate=16 June 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619205429/http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Lifestyle/Story/STIStory_390898.html |archivedate=19 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In a statement, Jacobs's family claimed that a scene in ''Goblet of Fire'' was substantially similar to Jacobs's book ''The Adventures of Willy the Wizard: Livid Land:'' "'Both Willy and Harry are required to work out the exact nature of the main task of the contest which they both achieve in a bathroom assisted by clues from helpers, in order to discover how to rescue human hostages imprisoned by a community of half-human, half-animal fantasy creatures."<ref name=straits /> They also launched a joint suit against Rowling and her publishers. Bloomsbury countered with a statement of its own, saying that "This claim is without merit and will be defended vigorously," and that Rowling "had never heard of Adrian Jacobs nor seen, read or heard of his book ''Willy the Wizard'' until this claim was first made in 2004, almost seven years after the publication of the first ''[[Harry Potter]]'' book."<ref name=straits /> The Jacobs estate, driven by [[Jon Jacobs (actor)|his son]] and grandson, have published a website with details and excerpts from the book, according to the ''[[Toronto Star]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=J.K. Rowling sued for plagiarism|author=Lesley Ciarula Taylor| url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/article/767464--j-k-rowling-sued-for-plagiarism|work=Toronto Star|accessdate=20 July 2010 | date=18 February 2010}}</ref> In July 2010, the estate filed suit against Rowling's American publisher, Scholastic, demanding that the company burn all copies of ''Goblet of Fire''.<ref>{{cite web|title= It's Harry Potter and the Allegation of Plagiarism|author=Karen Sloan|publisher=The National Law Journal|year=2010|url=http://www.law.com/jsp/cc/PubArticleCC.jsp?id=1202463556469&Its_Harry_Potter_and_the_Allegation_of_Plagiarism_|accessdate=15 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.moviefone.com/2010/02/18/j-k-rowling-accused-of-stealing-ideas-from-1987-childrens-wiza/|title=J.K. Rowling Accused of Stealing Ideas from 1987 Children's Wizard Book|publisher=|access-date=3 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703134826/http://news.moviefone.com/2010/02/18/j-k-rowling-accused-of-stealing-ideas-from-1987-childrens-wiza/#|archive-date=3 July 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 6 January 2011, the US lawsuit against Scholastic was dismissed. The judge in the case stated that there was not enough similarity between the two books to make a case for plagiarism.<ref>{{cite news|title=Harry Potter plagiarism case dismissed|publisher=BBC |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12134288|date=7 January 2011|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> In the UK courts, on 21 March 2011, Paul Allen, a trustee of the Jacobs estate, was ordered to pay as security to the court 65% of the costs faced by Bloomsbury and Rowling, amounting to over £1.5million, to avoid the claim being struck out. It was reported in ''The Bookseller''<ref>''The Bookseller'' Trustee of Willy the Wizard Makes Appeal over Court Costs (29 April 2011)</ref> that Paul Allen has appealed against paying this sum. As a condition of the appeal, he paid £50,000 to the court in May 2011.<ref>[http://www.thebookseller.com/news/willy-wizard-appeal-go-ahead-july.html?quicktabs_1=0 The Bookseller], 24 May 2011</ref> The claim was formally struck out in July 2011 after the deadline for Allen's initial payment was missed.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jul/18/harry-potter-plagiarism-struck-out|title=Harry Potter plagiarism claim struck out|date=18 July 2011|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
== International publications == {{See also|Tanya Grotter}} In 2002, an unauthorised Chinese-language sequel titled ''Harry Potter and Bao Zoulong'' (Chinese: Simplified: 哈利波特与豹走龙, Traditional: 哈利波特與豹走龍, [[Hanyu Pinyin]]: ''Hālì Bōtè yǔ Bào Zǒulóng'') appeared for sale in the People's Republic of China. (In English-language media this was mistranslated as ''Harry Potter and Leopard-Walk-Up-to-Dragon''.) According to translated excerpts, the book principally consists of the text of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Hobbit]]'', but with most names changed to those of ''Harry Potter'' characters.<ref name="i">{{cite news |author=David Eimer |title= Beatrix Potter court victory deals blow to China's publishing pirates |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/beatrix-potter-court-victory-deals-blow-to-chinas-publishing-pirates-506362.html |work=Independent on Sunday |publisher=Independent News and Media Limited |date=9 November 2005 |accessdate=6 August 2007 | location=London}}</ref> The book was quickly recognised by media outlets as a fake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsrss.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/2092661.stm|title=Fake Harry Potter novel hits China|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=8 January 2011|date=4 July 2002}}</ref> Rowling and [[Warner Bros.]] took steps to stop its distribution.<ref name="i" /> Copies were briefly distributed around the world, including [[e-book]] copies traded on the Internet. In November 2002, the Bashu Publishing House, in the southwestern city of [[Chengdu]], agreed to pay a £1,600 (US$3,400) fine and publish an apology in China's ''Legal Times'' for printing and distributing the novel.<ref name="t">[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article820428.ece Legal magic spells win for Harry in China] Oliver August and Jack Malvern, ''The Times'', 2002-11-02 Retrieved on: 2007-09-25</ref> As of 2007, the identity of the anonymous "author" has not been discovered. The opening of ''Harry Potter and Bao Zoulong'', translated into English, was included in several news articles.<ref name="t" /> As of 2007, it is estimated that there are fifteen million copies of fraudulent ''Harry Potter'' novels circulating in China.<ref name=China>{{cite web|title=What is the seventh Potter book called in China?|author=Howard W French|work=International Herald Tribune |date=31 July 2007|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/08/01/asia/01china.php|accessdate=1 August 2007}}</ref> In 2007, Rowling's agents, the [[Christopher Little Literary Agency]], began to discuss the possibility of legal proceedings concerning a fake version of ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'' that appeared in China ten days before the actual book's publication.<ref name=China />
In 2003, legal pressure from ''Harry Potter'''s publishers led an Indian publisher to stop publication of ''[[Harry Potter in Calcutta]]'' by Uttam Ghosh; a work in which Harry meets figures from [[Bengali literature]].<ref>Wu, Tim. "[http://www.slate.com/id/2084960/ Harry Potter and the International Order of Copyright]." ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''. Friday 27 June 2003. Retrieved 11 May 2009.</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Who won the race to translate ‘Harry Potter'?|author=William Sutton|work=The Times |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/children/article2645098.ece|accessdate=21 May 2009 | location=London | date=12 October 2007}}</ref> The case was settled out of court.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pirates Potter Around Kolkata|author=Chitra Subramanyam & Subrata Nagchoudhury|work=The Indian Express |year=2003|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/oldStory/22323/|accessdate=20 July 2010}}</ref>
Also in 2003, courts in the Netherlands prevented the distribution of a Dutch translation of ''[[Tanya Grotter and the Magical Double Bass]]'', the first of [[Dmitri Yemets]]' popular Russian series about a female apprentice wizard. Rowling and her publishers sued, arguing that the Grotter books violate [[copyright]] law. Yemets and his original Moscow-based publishers, [[Eksmo]], argued that the books constitute a parody, permitted under copyright.<ref name=yemets /> The Dutch courts ruled that the books did not constitute parody and thus were not allowed to be sold in the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rowling blocks Grotter release|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/2914111.stm|date=3 April 2003|accessdate=27 March 2007}}</ref> Later that year, as the Dutch translation ''Tanja Grotter en de magische contrabas'' was still legal in Belgium, the [[Flemish Region|Flemish]] publishers Roularta Books decided to print 1,000 copies (and no more) in order to let people decide whether it was [[plagiarism]], hoping that under those circumstances Rowling and her publishers would not sue.<ref name=Dutch>[http://binnenland.nieuws.nl/40972 'Tanja Grotter' wel in België te lezen] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720102716/http://binnenland.nieuws.nl/40972# |date=20 July 2011 }}, Nieuws.nl, 2003-09-25. Retrieved on 2008-09-25 (in Dutch)</ref> Rowling did not sue, but as there was a lot of interest in the book (Dutch people could buy the book by postal order from another Flemish publisher, Boekhandel VanIn) it was soon sold out.<ref name=Dutch /> The books continue to be published in Russia and have spawned several sequels.<ref>{{cite web|title=''Tanya Grotter'' title list|work=Tanya Grotter official site|url=http://www.grotter.ru/main.phtml?menu=book|accessdate=25 September 2008}} (in Russian)</ref>
In August 2008, Warner Bros. filed a lawsuit against production company [[Mirchi Movies]] due to the similarity of the title of their [[Bollywood]] film ''[[Hari Puttar: A Comedy of Terrors]]'' to the ''Harry Potter'' film series. Mirchi Movies CEO Munish Purii claimed there is very little similarity between Hari Puttar and any elements in the ''Harry Potter'' franchise, and explained that Hari is a popular Indian name, while "puttar" means "son" in [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], although Indian versions of ''Harry Potter'' also translate Harry's name to Hari Puttar.<ref>{{cite web|title=India's "Hari Puttar" caught in Harry Potter spell|work=NewsDaily|date=27 August 2008|url=http://www.newsdaily.com/stories/sp236913-india-potter/|accessdate=7 September 2008}}</ref> The film was delayed until late September. Warner Bros. claimed that the title was confusing, but Mirchi Movies claimed they registered the name in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|title=Court delays Puttar film release|author=Karishma Vaswani|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/7612809.stm|date=12 September 2008|accessdate=13 September 2008}}</ref> On 24 September 2008, the court in Delhi rejected Warner Bros.' claim, saying that ''Harry Potter'' readers were sufficiently able to distinguish between the two works. They also accused Warner Bros. of delaying the action, since they were aware of the film as far back as 2005.<ref>{{cite news|title=Harri Puttar free to cast its spell at Indian box-office|author=Anil Sinanan|work=The Times | location=London|date= 25 September 2008|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/bollywood/article4820747.ece|accessdate=25 September 2008}}</ref>
== Other accusations of infringement == {{See also|Warner Bros. and J. K. Rowling v. RDR Books}} In 2000, in the lead-up to the release of the first ''Harry Potter'' film, ''[[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)|Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone]]''; Warner Bros., the film's distributor, sent a series of letters to owners of ''Harry Potter'' fansites, demanding that, to protect their copyright, they hand over their domain names.<ref name=Claire /> The action resulted in negative publicity for the company when Claire Field, the then 15-year-old webmaster of the British fansite harrypotterguide.co.uk, was reduced to tears by what were described by her father as unnecessary bully tactics. Eventually the corporation backed down in the face of media opposition and declared that, as the site was non-commercial, it did not violate the trademark.<ref name=Claire /><ref>{{cite web|title=Warner Bros backs down on Harry Potter Web site|author=Kieren McCarthy|publisher=The Register|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2000/12/15/warner_bros_backs_down/ |date= 15 December 2000|accessdate=3 May 2007}}</ref>
In their May 2004 issue, the [[US Army]] publication ''[[PS, The Preventive Maintenance Monthly|The Preventive Maintenance Monthly]]'', which instructs soldiers on how to maintain their equipment, featured a spoof comic based on ''Harry Potter'', featuring a character named Topper who resided at Mogmarts School under Professor Rumbledore.<ref name=beeb /> The publication received notice from Rowling's lawyers that the comics breached copyright, though the magazine's editor, Ken Crunk, claimed that no violation had taken place, as "[t]he drawings do not look like any of the characters from ''Harry Potter''".<ref name=beeb>{{cite news|title=Army mag draws Potter comparisons|date=7 February 2005|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4243145.stm|accessdate=8 September 2007}}</ref> After a discussion with Rowling's representatives, the magazine agreed not to use the characters again.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arts, Briefly; Harry Potter Crosses Wands With the U.S. Army |author=Lizette Alvarez|work=The New York Times |date=9 February 2005|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A07E3DE163AF93AA35751C0A9639C8B63|accessdate=12 September 2008}}</ref>
In 2004, Rowling and Time Warner launched legal actions against bazee.com, now the Indian branch of the online auction site [[eBay]]. The site had hosted illegally created [[e-book]]s of ''Harry Potter'', which Rowling had never agreed to be published.<ref name=bazee>{{cite news|title=Potter author sues eBay over pirate books|author=Jack Malvern |work=The Times |date=26 February 2007|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article1437673.ece|accessdate=8 September 2008 | location=London}}</ref> In 2005, Rowling warned her fans on her website that various "signed" ''Harry Potter'' memorabilia appearing for sale on eBay did not in fact use her signature. She urged her fans to protest eBay to prevent other children from being swindled.<ref>{{cite web|title=E-Bay Users Once Again |author=JK Rowling |publisher=jkrowling.com |date=7 September 2005 |url=http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/news_view.cfm?id=88 |accessdate=8 September 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924152653/http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/news_view.cfm?id=88 |archivedate=24 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2007, Rowling launched lawsuits against a number of users of the site,<ref>{{cite web|title=Harry Potter author fights e-book fraud on eBay|author=Candace Lombardi|publisher=c:net|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-10784_3-6162935-7.html|accessdate=27 March 2007}}</ref> obtaining a series of stay orders preventing them from selling her work. However eBay claimed that in her dealings with the media, Rowling had falsely claimed that her injunctions had been against eBay itself.<ref name=delhi /> In June 2007, eBay filed papers with the [[Delhi High Court]], alleging that Rowling had caused them "immense humiliation and harassment".<ref name=delhi>{{cite web|title=JK Rowling badmouths eBay|author=Cade Metz|publisher=The Register|date=8 June 2007|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/06/08/rowling_badmouth_ebay/|accessdate=8 September 2008}}</ref> The High Court circumvented the application, claiming that it could not make such a judgment until the case went to trial.<ref name=delhi />
In October 2007, Warner Bros. sued a group constructing a façade during a [[Hindu]] [[Durga puja|religious festival]] in the Indian city of [[Kolkata]] for {{INRConvert|2|m|-3}}, claiming that they had erected a giant replica of Harry Potter's school, [[Hogwarts]], without their permission. Initial reports stated that, as the effort was not for profit, it did not violate Rowling's copyright.<ref name=afp>{{cite web|title=Rowling sues Indian festival for building replica of Hogwarts Castle|date=11 October 2007|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5j9arGtS_k-jLH7uhCX1K3V2GvMfw|agency=Agence France-Presse|accessdate=12 October 2007}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] claimed that the [[Delhi High Court|High Court of Delhi]], where the petition was filed, allowed the organisers to carry on with the temporary construction with an order that the structure had to be dismantled after the festival was over<ref name=afp /> and that the court refused to impose any compensation on the basis that the organisers were involved in a "non-profit making enterprise".<ref>Harish V Nair, 'Pottermania defeats Rowling at Salt Lake', ''[[Hindustan Times]]'', Kolkata Edition, 2007-10-13</ref> However, these statements were later retracted: the court had in fact ruled in favour of Warner Bros., but no fine had been ordered, and Warner Bros. claimed that they had only requested a fine because such action was necessary under Indian law.<ref>{{cite news|title=Correction: Festival-Harry Potter story|date=17 October 2007|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/10/17/asia/AS-GEN-India-Festival-Harry-Potter.php|accessdate=16 November 2007}}</ref> In November 2007, Rowling discussed the case on her website, listing the rumours that she had targeted a non-profit organisation as "Toxic" and saying, "The defendants were not religious charities, and theirs was not a religious celebration. On the contrary, it was a large-scale, commercial, sponsored event involving corporations that included a major Indian high street bank. The event was, however, set up while a Hindu festival was going on ... The court ruled that Warner Bros. rights had indeed been infringed, and that events such as the one in question would need Warner Bros.' permission in the future. The court also restrained all the defendants from any future events infringing Warner Bros. rights."<ref>{{cite web|title=Rubbish Bin: J K Rowling demands 2 million rupees from religious charities in India |publisher=jkrowling.com |author=JK Rowling |year=2007 |url=http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/rubbishbin_view.cfm?id=17 |accessdate=16 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116190947/http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/rubbishbin_view.cfm?id=17 |archivedate=16 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On 31 October 2007, Warner Bros. and Rowling sued Michigan-based publishing firm RDR Books to block the publication of a 400-page book version of the [[Harry Potter Lexicon]], an online reference guide to her work.<ref>{{cite web|author=David B. Caruso |title=Rowling Sues to Block Harry Potter Book |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=3803111 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=1 September 2007 |accessdate=1 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071102040520/http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=3803111 |archivedate=2 November 2007 }}</ref> Rowling, who previously had a good relationship with Lexicon owner [[Steve Vander Ark]], reiterated on her website that she plans to write a ''Harry Potter'' encyclopedia, and that the publication of a similar book before her own would hurt the proceeds of the official encyclopedia, which she plans to give to charity.<ref>{{cite web|author=Joanne Rowling |title=Companion Books |publisher=jkrowling.com |url=http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/news_view.cfm?id=102 |date=31 October 2007 |accessdate=1 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103154731/http://www.jkrowling.com/textonly/en/news_view.cfm?id=102 |archivedate= 3 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A judge later barred publication of the book in any form until the case was resolved.<ref>{{cite news|title=Row delays Harry Potter Lexicon|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7088336.stm|date=10 November 2007|accessdate=16 November 2007}}</ref> In their suit, Rowling's lawyers also asserted that, as the book describes itself as a print facsimile of the Harry Potter Lexicon website, it would publish excerpts from the novels and stills from the films without offering sufficient "transformative" material to be considered a separate work.<ref>{{cite news|title=Final (For Now!) Reflections on the Harry Potter Trial|author=Dan Slater |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=18 April 2008|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2008/04/18/final-for-now-reflections-on-the-harry-potter-trial/|accessdate=26 September 2008}}</ref> The trial concluded on 17 April 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rowling Says Fan's Book Could Endanger other Authors|work=[[Epoch Times]]|url=http://en.epochtimes.com/news/8-4-16/69301.html|date=16 April 2008 |accessdate=26 August 2008}}</ref> On 8 September 2008, the judge ruled in her favour, claiming that the book would violate the terms of fair use.<ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. judge halts unofficial Harry Potter lexicon|publisher=Reuters|date= 8 September 2008|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/entertainmentNews/idCAN0845394920080908|accessdate=9 September 2008}}</ref> In December, 2008, a modified (and shorter) version of Vander Ark's Lexicon was approved for publication and was released 16 January 2009 as ''The Lexicon: An Unauthorized Guide to Harry Potter Fiction''.
{{anchor|G. Norman Lippert}}In November 2007, ''[[The Scotsman]]'' reported that Rowling had threatened legal action against American computer programmer G. Norman Lippert for allegedly violating her [[intellectual property rights]] by producing and publishing the online novel, ''James Potter and the Hall of Elders' Crossing'', an [[Unauthorized#Publishing|unofficial and unauthorised]] continuation of the ''Harry Potter'' series. Written as a [[fan fiction]] project for Lippert's wife and sons, the novel is set eighteen years after the end of the last official installment in the series, ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'', and describes the adventures of [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]]'s son, [[James Potter II|James Sirius Potter]], during his first year at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]].<ref name="scotsman">{{cite web|url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/world/Rowling-goes-Potty-over-US.3538712.jp|last=Ross|first=Shan|title=Rowling goes Potty over US bid to post Harry's son's story on web|date=19 November 2007 |accessdate=19 November 2007|work=The Scotsman }}</ref> A specialist in intellectual property law at [[Strathclyde University]] commented that, "If an insubstantial character from a novel is taken and built up by another author in a new story, that can be a defence against copyright infringements."<ref name="scotsman" /> However, after Lippert offered Rowling an advance copy of the novel, Rowling dismissed her threat<ref name=gnorm /> and said she supported the novel and any others like it.<ref name=gnorm /> Lippert subsequently produced a sequel, ''James Potter and the Curse of the Gatekeeper''.<ref name=gnorm>{{cite web|title=On Eve of James Potter Sequel, Harry Potter fan Fiction Heats up: Unlikely Author Poised to Keep the Story Alive|publisher=PRWEB|year=2008|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2008/07/prweb1080574.htm|accessdate=20 July 2010}}</ref> After the novel first appeared online in early November 2007, some ''Harry Potter'' fans on the Internet initially speculated that the site might be part of an elaborate [[viral marketing]] campaign for an official continuation or spinoff of ''Harry Potter'', one either written or at least approved by Rowling herself.<ref>{{cite news|author=Schliebs, Mark |title=Web abuzz with Harry Potter sequel rumours |date=9 November 2007 |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/story/0,23663,22729888-10388,00.html?from=mostpop |accessdate=9 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109180559/http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/story/0%2C23663%2C22729888-10388%2C00.html?from=mostpop |archivedate= 9 November 2007 |df= }}</ref> On 9 November 2007, Rowling's agent Neil Blair denied that Rowling was in any way involved with the purported project,<ref>{{cite web|author=Maughan, Shannon |title=RDR Books Agrees to Delay Potter Title |date=9 November 2007 |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6499333.html |accessdate=28 March 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213062816/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6499333.html |archivedate=13 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and [[Warner Bros.]], the studio which owns the rights to the [[Harry Potter film series|''Harry Potter'' film series]], denied that the novel was in any way connected to the official ''Harry Potter'' franchise.<ref>{{cite web|author=CHEESER |title=Elder's Crossing, James Potter, Book 8, RIP |date=9 November 2007 |url=http://www.hpana.com/news.20263.html |accessdate=9 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111131707/http://www.hpana.com/news.20263.html |archivedate=11 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Legal injunctions == [[File:Harry Potter VI boxes.jpg|thumb|300 px|Boxes of ''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince'' awaiting delivery]] Rowling and her publishers have brought a series of legal [[injunction]]s to ensure the books' secrecy before their launch. These injunctions have drawn criticism from [[civil liberties]] campaigners over their potentially sweeping powers over individual freedoms.
In 2003, in an attempt to maintain secrecy over the impending release of the fifth ''Harry Potter'' book, ''[[Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix]]'', Rowling and her publishers sought and received a groundbreaking injunction against "the person or persons who has or have physical possession of a copy of the said book or any part thereof without the consent of the Claimants".<ref name=injunction /> The ruling obtained, for the first time in British law, an injunction against unnamed or unknown individuals; before then, injunctions could only be obtained against named individuals. Lawyers Winterbothams noted that, "The new ''Harry Potter'' style injunction could be used if you expected a demonstration or trespass to take place, but which had not yet begun, so long as you could find a description for the people expected which the Court was satisfied identified 'those who are included and those who are not'".<ref name=injunction /> The "Potter injunction" was later used against a camp of [[Romani people|Roma]] travellers.<ref name=injunction /> In 2006, pharmaceutical company [[GlaxoSmithKline]] employed the injunction against anonymous animal rights campaigners who had sent threatening letters to their investors.<ref>{{cite news|title=Animal extremists can no longer hide behind a web of secrecy |author=Dan Tench |work=The Times | location=London |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/article722258.ece |date= 23 May 2006 |accessdate=30 May 2007}}</ref>
The series garnered more controversy in 2005 with the release of the sixth book, ''[[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince]]'', when a [[Real Canadian Superstore]] grocery store accidentally sold several copies before the authorised release date. The Canadian publisher, [[Raincoast Books]], obtained an injunction from the [[Supreme Court of British Columbia]] prohibiting the purchasers from reading the books in their possession. A comment by a media lawyer that "there is no human right to read" led to a debate in the public sphere about whether free access to information was a human right. [[Michael Geist]], the [[Canada Research Chair]] of Internet and E-commerce Law at the [[University of Ottawa]], said in response, "The copyright law claim was particularly puzzling. While copyright law does provide copyright owners with a basket of exclusive rights, the right to prohibit reading is not among them. In fact, copyright law has very little to say about what people can do with a book once they have purchased it."<ref name=geist /><ref>{{cite news|title=Reading ban on leaked Harry Potter |author=Jack Malvern |work=The Times | location=London|date= 13 July 2005|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article543318.ece|accessdate=11 October 2007}}</ref> Free-speech activist [[Richard Stallman]] posted a statement on his blog calling for a boycott until the publisher issued an apology.<ref name="Don't Buy Harry Potter Books" /> Solicitors Fraser Milner and Casgrain, who represented Raincoast and formulated the legal argument for the embargo,<ref>{{cite web|title=Important Notice: Raincoast Books |publisher=Raincoast Books |url=http://www.raincoast.com/harrypotter/injunction-commentary.html |date= 25 August 2005|accessdate=27 October 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071018031618/http://www.raincoast.com/harrypotter/injunction-commentary.html |archivedate = 18 October 2007}}</ref> have rebutted this, saying that the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] applies only to the government, not to private litigation, and does not offer any protection of the right to read in any case, and the innocent purchasers of the ''Harry Potter'' book had no more right to read it than if they had come into possession of someone's secret diary.<ref>{{cite web|title=Understanding the Harry Potter Injunction: Protecting Copyright and Confidential Information |author=Barbara Grossman, Aaron Milrad and Annie Na |publisher=Fraser Milner and Casgrain |url=http://www.fmc-law.com/upload/en/publications/20052006/655380_HarryPotterInjunction_October21_2005.pdf |format=PDF|year=2005 |accessdate=30 May 2007}}</ref>
In 2007, [[Scholastic Corporation]] threatened legal action against two booksellers, Levy Home Entertainment and DeepDiscount.com, for selling copies of the final novel, ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'', before its release date of 21 July. In an official statement, Scholastic appealed "to the ''Harry Potter'' fans who bought their books from DeepDiscount.com and may receive copies early requesting that they keep the packages hidden until midnight on 21 July."<ref>{{cite news|title=Scholastic will take action against Harry Potter distributors |publisher=Reuters |date=18 July 2007 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/industryNews/idUSWEN939320070718 |accessdate=18 July 2007}}</ref> Customers who agreed not to read the book received a special ''Harry Potter'' t-shirt and a $50 coupon for Scholastic's online store.
== Blackmail == In June 2005, Aaron Lambert, a security guard at a book distribution centre in [[Corby]], Northamptonshire, England, stole a number of pages from ''[[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince]]'' six weeks before its intended publication date. He was arrested a day later after negotiations to sell them to John Askill, a journalist from ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', turned violent. Lambert reportedly fired a shot from his imitation [[Walther PPK]] pistol, but Askill was unharmed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guard admits to Harry Potter theft|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/northamptonshire/4327346.stm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080124150123/http://www.jrrobertssecurity.com/security-news/security-crime-news0082.htm|archivedate=24 January 2008|date=13 October 2005|accessdate=23 May 2007}}</ref> At his trial the following October, Lambert pleaded guilty to threatening Askill and to attempting to blackmail ''Harry Potter'''s publishers, [[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Potter book thief admits threats|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/northamptonshire/4546164.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=20 December 2005|accessdate=23 May 2007}}</ref> In January 2006, Lambert was sentenced to four and a half years in prison.<ref name=corby /> In November 2011, in her testimony before the [[Leveson Inquiry]], Rowling said that the ''Sun'' had attempted to "blackmail" her into a photo-op in return for returning the stolen manuscript.<ref name=cnn1>{{cite web|title=J.K. Rowling chased from home by press, she says|author=Richard Allen Greene|publisher=CNN|year=2011|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/24/world/europe/uk-phone-hacking-scandal/?hpt=wo_bn6|accessdate=25 November 2011}}</ref>
== Accusation of libel == In July 2007, a dispute arose between ''Harry Potter'''s British publisher, [[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury]], and [[Asda]], a British supermarket chain owned by the US corporation [[Wal-Mart]]. On 15 July, a week before the release of the final ''Harry Potter'' novel, ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'', Asda issued a press release accusing Bloomsbury of unfairly fixing their prices. Asda spokesman Peter Pritchard claimed that Bloomsbury was "holding children to ransom" and that, "[i]t seems like Bloomsbury need to do a [[Quidditch|quid-ditch]] as they have sent their prices up north on the [[Hogwarts Express]]. By setting the [[Suggested retail price|recommended retail price]] at this level can only be seen {{sic}} as blatant profiteering on their part." Pritchard went on to say that Asda was acting to "champion the right of young readers", and that the recommended retail price was "twice the average child's pocket money and £5 more than the average children's bestseller".<ref name=telegraph /> Asda had planned to sell the book as a [[loss leader]] at £8.87 ($16.30), or half Bloomsbury's [[recommended retail price]] of £17.99 ($33.00) and below the wholesale price of £9.89 ($18.00).
Two days later, Bloomsbury responded that the claims were "potentially libellous" and that: <blockquote> Asda's latest attempt to draw attention to themselves involves trying to leap on the ''Harry Potter'' bandwagon. This is just another example of their repeated efforts of appearing as Robin Hood in the face of controversy about their worldwide group, which would suggest they are perceived as more akin to the Sheriff of Nottingham. Loss leaders were invented by supermarkets and have nothing to do with Bloomsbury Publishing or ''Harry Potter'' and we deeply regret having been dragged into their price-wars.<ref name=telegraph /> </blockquote> Bloomsbury stated that the price hike of £1 from the previous ''Harry Potter'' novel was due to it having been printed on recycled paper. "There is a price to be paid by the consumer for environmental best practice", a Bloomsbury spokeswoman said.<ref name=makepeace>{{cite web|title=Bloomsbury: Asda must make peace|author=Katherine Rushton|publisher=thebookseller.com|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/42122-bloomsbury-asda-must-make-peace.html|date=17 July 2007|accessdate=1 August 2007}}</ref>
Bloomsbury CEO Nigel Newton said, "[They have] unleashed a very disingenuous, self-interested attack on us. This is complete nonsense and all they're doing is grandstanding as they've done on the price of aspirin and bread. They try to turn it into a big deal as though it's a moral crusade for them, but it's nothing of the kind."<ref name=makepeace />
That same day, Bloomsbury cancelled all Asda's orders of ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows'', or roughly 500,000 copies, citing unpaid bills from the company totalling £38,000 ($70,000) for unauthorised returns of the sixth ''Harry Potter'' book.<ref name=makepeace /> "The two matters are completely unrelated", said a Bloomsbury spokeswoman, "We decided today that we couldn't risk having arrears with anybody."<ref name=telegraph /> The dispute had been "going on a while – going on for weeks actually."<ref name=lifestyle>{{cite web|title=Asda Apologises following Potter Book Row|publisher=UK News Lifestyle Extra|url=http://www.lifestyleextra.com/ShowStory.asp?story=BZ1739815T&news_headline=asda_apologises_following_potter_book_row__|date=17 July 2007|accessdate=1 August 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713204528/http://www.lifestyleextra.com/ShowStory.asp?story=BZ1739815T&news_headline=asda_apologises_following_potter_book_row__#|archive-date=13 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Asda responded that Bloomsbury owed them £122,000 ($224,000) ("for pulping and for other book trade issues and work we have done for them"<ref name=makepeace />) and that, as one company spokesman claimed, "It just seems funny that after we expose the potty Potter price hike, Bloomsbury are trying everything they can to stop kids getting hold of ''Harry Potter'' at a price they can afford."
Asda paid the bill within hours, and claimed that Bloomsbury would be in breach of contract if it did not allow the store to sell its books. However, Bloomsbury claimed that the block on Asda's orders was still in place as, "Unfortunately, we've now had to initiate a significant libel claim against them. That matter will have to be dealt with. If they want their 500,000 books, they'll have to come and make peace with us ... It could be good news for all their disappointed customers, because they don't have to go to a soulless Asda shed to buy their book and they can share the magic of ''Harry Potter'' at an independent or specialist bookstore instead."<ref name=makepeace />
Upon receipt of Bloomsbury's legal letter, Asda responded that, "There is nothing defamatory in our press release. Everything there is factual. It is a commentary on how we see things."<ref name=makepeace /> Said another Asda spokesperson, "If they don't supply us with the books, it will have a massive implication and [be] a breach of contract – but I don't think they will do that."<ref name=makepeace />
Later that day, however, Asda released a statement retracting its original comment: "We apologise unreservedly to Bloomsbury for [our] press release dated 15 July and withdraw our statement. We look forward to a good relationship with Bloomsbury going forward, including selling the latest ''Harry Potter'' book from 00:01 am BST on Saturday 21 July and many other Bloomsbury books in the future".<ref>{{cite web|title=Asda apologises to Bloomsbury|author=Philip Jones |publisher=thebookseller.com|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/42186-asda-apologises-to-bloomsbury.html|date=17 July 2007|accessdate=1 August 2007}}</ref> In response, Bloomsbury lifted the block and Asda was allowed to sell its books. The original press release was then expunged.<ref name=guardian>{{cite news|title=Harry Potter and the Asda Apology|author=Graeme Warden|work=The Guardian |location=London|date=17 July 2007|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/jul/17/harrypotter.supermarkets|accessdate=1 August 2007 }}</ref>
The rationale behind Asda's initial press release remains uncertain. Neill Denny, commentator for thebookseller.com, opined that "the whole episode has the whiff of a badly-conceived PR stunt by ill-briefed senior executives at Asda out of touch with the subtleties of the book world."<ref name=Denny>{{cite web|title=Opinion: Asda's climbdown|author=Neill Denny|publisher=thebookseller.com|date=17 July 2007|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/42197-opinion-asdas-climbdown.html|accessdate=1 August 2007}}</ref> Ralph Baxter of Publishing News concurred: "For Asda ... it may be seen as mission accomplished, a high-risk strategy to maximise publicity for its ''Harry Potter'' offer rewarded with television, radio, Internet and newspaper coverage. And the association of Asda with low prices has no doubt been entrenched in a few more minds."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Great Stand-Off|author=Ralph Baxter|work=Publishing News Online|url=http://www.publishingnews.co.uk/pn/pno-news-display.asp?K=e2007071912471094&TAG=&CID=&PGE=&sg9t=... |year=2007|accessdate=1 August 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071113192945/http://www.publishingnews.co.uk/pn/pno-news-display.asp?K=e2007071912471094&TAG=&CID=&PGE=&sg9t=... |archivedate = 13 November 2007}}</ref>

{{for|the legal status of the psychoactive substance found in ''Salvia divinorum''|Salvinorin A#Legal status}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Legal status of ''Salvia divinorum''}} {{Psychedelic sidebar}} '''''[[Salvia divinorum]]''''', a [[psychoactive]] plant, is legal in most countries. Exceptions, countries where there is some form of control, include [[Australia]], [[Belgium]], [[Brazil]], [[Canada]], [[Denmark]], [[Estonia]], [[Finland]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], [[South Korea]], [[Poland]], [[Spain]], [[Sweden]], [[Armenia]] and the [[Legal status of Salvia divinorum in the United States|United States]].<ref name="SiebertLegalStatus">[[#refSiebertLegalStatus|Siebert (Legal status)]].</ref><ref name="ErowidLegalStatus">[[#refErowidLegalStatus|Erowid (Legal status)]].</ref>
In the United Kingdom, following a local newspaper story in October 2005,<ref name="Worksop20051014">[[#refWorksop20051014|Worksop 2005-10-14 (UK Media)]].</ref> a parliamentary [[Early Day Motion]] was raised calling for ''Salvia divinorum'' to be banned there. However, it only received 11 signatures.<ref name="Mann2005">[[#refMann2005|Mann 2005]].</ref> A second Early Day Motion was raised in October 2008 attracting 18 signatures.<ref name="Early day motion 2235">[http://www.parliament.uk/edm/2007-08/2235 Early day motion 2235]. Parliament UK. Retrieved 12 July 2017.</ref> The [[Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs]], the independent body that advises UK government on drugs, has been asked to investigate further.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/apr/26/drugs-legal-substances-highs There are many drugs that help people get out of their minds yet stay within the law - they're called 'legal highs']. The Guardian. Published 26 April 2009. Retrieved 12 July 2017.</ref> On the 28 January 2016, the [[Psychoactive Substances Act 2016]] was passed. The act came into force on 26 May 2016, across the entire United Kingdom, making ''salvia'' illegal to possess with intent to supply, possess on custodial premises, supply, import for human consumption, or produce for human consumption.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2016/2/contents Psychoactive Substances Act 2016]. ''Legislation.gov''. Retrieved 19 October 2018.</ref> The two sponsors for the bill were [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[House of Lords]] member [[Michael Bates, Baron Bates|Michael Bates]] and Conservative [[Member of parliament|MP]] [[Theresa May]].<ref>[http://services.parliament.uk/bills/2015-16/psychoactivesubstances.html Psychoactive Substances Act 2016]. Parliament. Retrieved 7 May 2017.</ref>
In such places where ''Salvia divinorum'' legislation exists, it varies in prohibitive degree from country to country. Australia has imposed its strictest 'Schedule 9' (US Schedule I equivalent or equivalent to class A in the UK) classification, for example, and Italy has also placed Salvia in its 'Table I' of controlled substances (also US Schedule I and class A equivalent). In Spain there are just controls focusing on the commercial trade of ''Salvia divinorum'', and private cultivation (growing one's own plants for non-commercial use) is not targeted.
In the United States, Salvia is not regulated under the [[Controlled Substances Act]] but some states, including Delaware, Illinois, Louisiana, Missouri, Virginia, Tennessee, Texas, and others, have passed their own laws.<ref>[[#refDEA2007|DEA 2007]].</ref> Several other states have proposed legislation against Salvia, including Alabama, Alaska, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Oregon, and Pennsylvania. Many of these proposals have not made it into law, with motions having failed, stalled or otherwise died, for example at committee review stages.<ref name="SiebertLegalStatus" /><ref name="ErowidLegalStatus" />
National legislation for amendment of the Controlled Substances Act to place salvinorin A and ''Salvia divinorum'' in Schedule I at the federal level was proposed in 2002 by [[Rep. Joe Baca|Representative Joe Baca]] ([[United States Democratic Party|D]]- California). Those opposed to bill HR 5607 include [[Daniel Siebert (ethnobotanist)|Daniel Siebert]], who sent a letter to Congress arguing against the proposed legislation,<ref name="Siebert2002">[[#refSiebert2002|Siebert 2002]].</ref> and the Center for Cognitive Liberty & Ethics (CCLE), who sent key members of the US Congress a report on ''Salvia divinorum'' and its active principle,<ref name="Boire2002">[[#refBoire2002|Boire 2002]].</ref> along with letters from an array of scientists who expressed concern that scheduling ''Salvia divinorum'' would negatively impact important research on the plant. The bill did not pass.<ref name="Baca2002">[[#refBaca2002|Baca 2002]].</ref><ref>[[#refDEA2003|DEA 2003]].</ref><ref name="CCLE2002">[[#refCCLE2002b|CCLE 2002b]].</ref>
Salvia cultivation may prove difficult to police. The plant has a nondescript appearance; unlike cannabis the leaves are not distinctive and it does not have a distinctive odour. ''Salvia divinorum'' looks like and can be grown as an ordinary [[houseplant]] without the need of special equipment such as [[hydroponic]]s or high-power lights.<ref name="Shulgin2003">[[#refShulgin2003|Shulgin 2003]].</ref><ref name="Chalmers20060506 ">[[#refChalmers20060506|Chalmers 2006-05-06 (US Media)]].</ref> {{TOC right}}
==Opinions and arguments== Concerns expressed by some politicians on the subject of Salvia echo those of the media. In November 2006, the morning after a story by news channel KSL was aired in Utah, warning its viewers about what it called "this dangerous herb",<ref name="Dujanovic20061127">[[#refDujanovic20061127|Dujanovic 2006-11-27 (US Media).]]</ref> Utah State Representative [[Paul Ray]] (R) submitted a bill calling for its Schedule I classification in that state. KSL TV cameras were on Capitol Hill to see the paperwork filed, with KSL reporting - "Moments after our story ended, Utah Representative Paul Ray began writing a bill to ban Salvia." As he presented the bill Ray said - "It was upsetting to see we have a drug of that strength that's legal." and "We're basically going to make it illegal to possess or sell. Period."<ref name="Dujanovic20061128">[[#refDujanovic20061128|Dujanovic 2006-11-28 (US Media)]].</ref> Ray's action was further supported by the news channel in a subsequent KSL editorial. Viewer feedback was unanimously more critical.<ref name="Cardall20061128">[[#refCardall20061212|Cardall 2006-12-12 (US Media).]]</ref>
Georgia State Senator John Bulloch (R) reportedly saw a report on an Atlanta television news station about the increased use of ''Salvia divinorum''. He was quoted as saying - "I thought, 'Why hasn't somebody already jumped on this?" before filing Senate Bill 295. "I hurriedly got legislative counsel to draft the bill.... Everything that I read about it is it's considered to be a hallucinogenic drug.... A lot of the reading that I've found on it says that it gives a quicker and more intense high than LSD." Senator Don Thomas (R) was reported as saying -"I just know about the publicity of the dangers of it, and the use of it, so my first impression is to ban anything of that nature."<ref>[[#refEckenrode20070308|Eckenrode 2007-03-08 (US Media)]].</ref>
In February 2007, the day after a Fox TV local news story on Salvia had aired in Milwaukee,<ref name="Sanchick20070214">[[#refSanchick20070214|Sanchick 2007-02-14 (US Media).]]</ref> Wisconsin state lawmaker [[Sheldon Wasserman]] (D), also a licensed physician, who had never heard of it before, spoke to Fox news in a follow-up report about then wanting to make it a Schedule I controlled substance.<ref name="Sanchick20070215">[[#refSanchick20070215|Sanchick 2007-02-15 (US Media)]].</ref>
Comparisons to LSD and particular focus on "protecting our children" are also echoed by politicians. In June 2007 the Wisconsin State Journal newspaper ran a front-page headline cover story about Salvia, reporting that Representative Wasserman had recently begun seeking sponsors for a bill that would ban the manufacture and sale of ''Salvia divinorum'' for consumption in Wisconsin. Dr. Wasserman was reported as saying - "This bill is all about protecting our children" and "I want to stop the Salvia divinorum dealers who are pushing young people to experiment with a potentially dangerous substance."<ref name="Martell20070618">[[#refMartell20070618|Martell 2007-06-18 (US Media).]]</ref>
In connection with his proposals to make ''Salvia divinorum'' and salvinorin A Schedule I controlled substances in Oregon, Representative [[John Lim]] (R) was quoted as saying - "From what I understand this drug is at least as dangerous as marijuana or LSD", and Seth Hatmaker, a spokesman for Lim - "I think it's only a matter of time before we find people addicted to this stuff".<ref name="Clark20070305">[[#refClark20070305|Clark 2007-03-05 (US Media)]].</ref>
In the state of Illinois, in support of his bill for Schedule I classification of ''Salvia divinorum'', Representative [[Dennis Reboletti]] (R) wrote in his own website that Salvia is a "powerful psychoactive plant which in appearance looks like marijuana but has the psychoactive properties of LSD." and "It's important that we in the legislature are proactive in protecting our children from highly addictive substances" [...] "For a drug to be classified as a Schedule 1 substance signifies that it's a highly dangerous and potentially lethal drug for its user. Hopefully, the passage of my bill will bring attention to "Magic Mint" and help law enforcement combat the future rise of this drug."<ref name="Reboletti2007Mar">[[#refReboletti2007Mar|Reboletti 2007 (Mar)]].</ref>
Other references and sources indicate however that ''Salvia divinorum'' does not look like marijuana. Its psychoactive properties are not like those of LSD, and that Salvia divinorum is not generally understood to be either addictive or toxic.
Concerns about driving while under the influence of Salvia have also been expressed. Delaware State Senator Karen Peterson (D), who introduced Schedule I classification of ''Salvia divinorum'' in Delaware, said - "I, for one, don't want to be driving down Route 1 next to someone who is having an out-of-body experience"<ref>[[#refNBC1020060411|NBC10 2006-04-11 (US Media)]].</ref> and "I thought this is not something that I would want people using driving around the streets of Delaware."<ref>[[#refSmith20070925|Smith 2007-09-25 (US Media)]].</ref>
There has not been any evidence to suggest that Salvia use is problematic. Some "arguments" against Salvia have been of a preventative or imitative nature. North Dakota State Senator Randy Christmann (R) stated - "we need to stop this before it gets to be a huge problem not after it gets to be a huge problem"<ref name="KXMBTV20070131">[[#refKXMBTV20070131|KXMBTV 2007-01-31 (US Media)]].</ref> and New Jersey Assemblyman [[Jack Conners]] (D) argued -"Salvia divinorum use may not be a runway epidemic, but it's certainly is a phenomenon that warrants attention. We should take preventive steps now to prevent wholesale problems later on"<ref name="Teel2006">[[#refTeel2006|Teel 2006]].</ref> In October 2005 MP [[John Mann (British politician)|John Mann]] raised an ultimately unsuccessful [[Early Day Motion]] calling for ''Salvia divinorum'' to be banned in the UK, saying - "The Australians have clearly found a problem with it. There's obviously a risk in people taking it."<ref name="Worksop20051014" />
The National Institute on Money in State Politics indicates the major sources of campaign contributions for US politicians. For example, Oregon State Representative John Lim's largest individual campaign sponsor in 2006 was the Oregon Beer & Wine Distributors Association. Lim argued for Schedule I classification of Salvia in Oregon. Senator Karen Peterson's second largest group campaign donations in 2006 came from 'Beer, Wine & Liquor' industries. Peterson introduced Schedule I classification of ''Salvia divinorum'' in Delaware. Tennessee State Senator [[Tim Burchett]] (R) sponsored Salvia legislation in Tennessee. In 2006 his second largest individual campaign donation came from the Tennessee Malt Beverage Association. In the same period alcohol and tobacco related contributions amounted to the fourth largest industry contributions for Representative Paul Ray in Utah. Alcohol related contributions also featured highly for Representative Dennis Reboletti in Illinois - 'Beer, Wine & Liquor' was his seventh highest industry contributor.<ref name="MiSP2006">[[#refMiSP2006|MiSP 2006]].</ref>
Opponents of more prohibitive measures against Salvia argue that such reactions are largely due to an inherent prejudice and a particular cultural bias rather than any actual balance of evidence, pointing out inconsistencies in attitudes toward other more toxic and addictive drugs such as [[alcohol]] and [[nicotine]].<ref>[[#refNutt2007|Nutt et al. 2007]].</ref> The worldwide number of alcohol-related deaths is calculated at over 2,000 people per day,<ref>[[#refLopez2005|Lopez 2005]], Table 2.</ref> in the US the number is over 300 deaths per day.<ref>[[#refNIAAA2001|NIAAA 2001]].</ref> While not objecting to some form of legal control, in particular with regard to the sale to minors or sale of enhanced high-strength extracts, most Salvia proponents otherwise argue against stricter legislation.<ref name="SiebertLegalStatus" />
Those advocating consideration of ''Salvia divinorum'''s potential for beneficial use in a modern context have two major arguments: First that Salvia Divinorum is a potent kappa opioid agonist and given its activity and modulatory effect on the [[kappa opioid receptor]], and therefore similarity of its profile of effect to [[ibogaine]], (used successfully to treat addiction around the world) that further research into its potential as a potent anti-addiction medication<ref name="pmid15542743">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hasebe K, Kawai K, Suzuki T, Kawamura K, Tanaka T, Narita M, Nagase H, Suzuki T | title = Possible pharmacotherapy of the opioid kappa receptor agonist for drug dependence | journal = Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences | volume = 1025 | issue = | pages = 404–13 |date=October 2004 | pmid = 15542743 | doi = 10.1196/annals.1316.050 | url = }}</ref> will be hindered by careless lawmaking. Secondly, advocates argue that more could be learned from Mazatec culture, where Salvia is not really associated with notions of drug taking at all and it is rather considered as a spiritual sacrament. In light of this it is argued that ''Salvia divinorum'' could be better understood more positively as an [[entheogen]] rather than pejoratively as a [[hallucinogen]].<ref name="BlosserLessons">[[#refBlosserLessons|Blosser (Mazatec Lessons)]].</ref> Other entheogenic plants with continuing traditions principally of spiritual use include [[peyote]] (and other psychoactive cacti), [[iboga]], [[virola]], [[ayahuasca]] (an admixture of plants containing [[Dimethyltryptamine|DMT]] + [[MAOI]]), and various types of psychoactive fungi.<ref name="OtherEntheogenicPlants">see [[peyote]], [[iboga]], [[virola]], [[ayahuasca]], etc.</ref> In fact, US legislation as it stands specifically allows two of these to be used in a spiritual context. The [[Native American Church]] is allowed to use peyote and [[União do Vegetal]] (or UDV) is permitted ayahuasca.<ref name="USLegislation">see [[Native American Church]] and [[União do Vegetal]].</ref> Although not consistently granted (varying from state to state), the principal grounds for such concessions are constitutional,<ref>[[#refMadison1789|Madison 1789]].</ref> with further grounds following from the [[Religious Freedom Restoration Act]].

"Salvia Divinorum is a hallucinogenic drug, which has been banned in Australia, and yet here in New Zealand it continues to be sold freely." and "We’re dealing with a dangerous drug here, with the minister's wait and see approach like playing Russian Roulette with young people's lives."<ref>[[#refNZNP20071105|New Zealand National Party 2007-11-05 (NZ Media)]].</ref> Jacqui Dean has similar concerns about the 'party pill' [[benzylpiperazine]] (BZP), over which Associate Health Minister [[Jim Anderton]] ([[New Zealand Progressive Party|Progressive party]]) has accused her of indulging in political grandstanding, saying - "Perhaps Mrs Dean doesn't subscribe to the idea that any Government must balance the need to act promptly with its responsibilities to act fairly and follow due process, particularly where its actions affect those who are currently acting within existing legal constraints."<ref>[[#refAnderton2007|Anderton 2007]].</ref> When questioned by [[Māori Party]] MP [[Tariana Turia]], on why she was unwilling to take the same prohibitory line on smoking cigarettes and drinking alcohol as she took on BZP Ms Dean said "Alcohol and tobacco have been with our society for many, many years."<ref>[[#refStuff20071010|Stuff 2007-10-10 (NZ Media)]].</ref> In September 2007, the Social Tonics Association of New Zealand (STANZ) called for Jacqui Dean to step down from speaking on drug issues after she demonstrated "a lack of credibility in calling for the [[Dihydrogen monoxide hoax|ban of dihydrogen monoxide]] (H<sub>2</sub>O - i.e. water.)" STANZ Chairman Matt Bowden said - "The DHMO hoax played on the member this week is not a joke, it highlights a serious issue at the heart of drug policy making. Ms Dean demonstrated a ‘ban anything moderately harmful’ reflex. This approach is just downright dangerous." - "Jacqui Dean has clearly demonstrated a lack of credibility in her requests to the Minister to consider banning water; She has also seriously embarrassed her National Party colleagues who can no longer have confidence in her petitions to ban BZP or anything else."<ref>[[#refSTA20070915|Social Tonics Association 2007-09-15 (NZ Media)]].</ref>
